revision.text: {{also| xiùcaí}} ==English== {{wikipedia}} ===Etymology=== {{translit|en|cmn|-}} {{zh-l|秀才}} via {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|en|/ʃjoʊˈtsaɪ/}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun|xiucai}} # {{lb|en|historical}} In ancient China, a [[scholar]] who has [[pass]]ed the entry-level examination to study at a [[college]]. #: {{syn|en|shengyuan}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1992 |last=Chang |first=Chun-shu |author2=Hsueh-lun Chang |chapter=Crisis and Revolution in the Ming-Ch'ing Intellectual World: Li Yü's World in Historical Perspective |title={{w|Crisis and Transformation in Seventeenth-Century China|Crisis and Transformation in Seventeenth-Century China: Society, Culture, and Modernity in Li Yü's World}} |url=https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780472085286/ |edition=Paperback |year_published=1998 |location=[[Ann Arbor]] |publisher={{w|University of Michigan Press}} |ISBN=0-472-10255-9 |LCCN=91-25205 |OCLC=39336262 |pages=285-286 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780472085286/page/285/ |text=The author of ''The Compendium of Materia Medica'' was Li Shih-chen (1518-93), a pioneering scholar in the field of medicinal research in the late Ming. A native of Ch’i-chou in Hukuang (modern Ch’i-ch’un in Hupei), Li Shih-chen achieved the first-degree '''''hsiu-ts'ai''''' in 1531, but gave up obtaining the second-degree ''chü-jen'' after three unsuccessful attempts between 1534 and 1540. |brackets=on}}
